title: 112_s545
content: Establishment of Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000. The President shall establish an Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health within 120 days of the enactment of this section. The Board will provide advice to the President on worker health issues and ensure a balanced membership representing various perspectives. The Advisory Board on Toxic Substances and Worker Health will provide advice to the President on various issues, including reviewing and approving the Department of Labor site exposure matrix, conducting peer reviews of medical guidance for claims examiners, obtaining expert reviews of medical evidentiary requirements for lung disease claims, overseeing consulting physicians, and coordinating data exchanges with the Advisory Board on Radiation and Worker Health. The President will appoint a staff to support the Board's work. The Board, headed by a Director appointed under subchapter VIII of chapter 33 of title 5, U.S. Code, may have Federal agency personnel detailed to it as needed. The Board shall have powers similar to the Advisory Board under section 3624. Members, excluding full-time U.S. employees, attending Board meetings or serving at the President's request away from home, are entitled to travel and meal expenses. The Board allows travel and meal expenses, including per diem, for Federal Government individuals serving without pay. The Secretary of Energy must ensure Board members and staff have the opportunity to apply for security clearances. The Secretary of Energy must provide a report to Congress on security clearance applications, grants, and denials. The Board and its contractors have access to relevant information, including restricted data and Privacy Act information. The Department of Labor responds to the Office of the Ombudsman. The Department of Labor must respond to the Office of the Ombudsman's annual report within 90 days, stating whether they agree or disagree with the issues raised and outlining actions to address any identified problems. The response must be posted on the Department's public website.
